description.text:
For Prusa Mendel model.
This guide is 3 pieces. A left, a right bracket and a center guide that connects via dovetail joints.Make one of each. It allows the filament to slide back and fourth with the movement of the extruder head.

Make one left, one right bracket, and one middle bracket.
Recommend printing with a brim and cleaning it off after. The center guide is rounded with a fillet and prints nicer with the brim.
Be sure to clean parts well and sand the center part to make the fillet smooth.
Sand dovetail joints so they fit nicely (tight but removable)
Optional: In mine, i like the ability to remove the guide without disconnecting my filament from my extruder. So i heated an xacto knife over the stove flame and cut the end of the center bracket right thru the dovetail. See the screen shots.
my thirth thing uploaded :D (im Dutch)
made with 123d design autodesk

title: Filament Guide v4 - revised S slot

description.text: This is a modified version of Blackice83's guide. The slot that allows for sliding the filament in and out has been altered to an S shape to prevent the filament jumping out during printing.

I tried this guide and it works great. When i was drawing it, my goal was to make the spool feed to the extruder as fluid and smooth as possible with the least amount of force needed to pull in filament. So with this design i noted, when the extruder head goes far left or right along the X axis, it does put a small amount of tension on the filament because this guide is typically positioned in the middle. To resolve that I build a wide mount variation that comes in 3 parts witha dove tail fit connection. It works like a charm http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:62386

This is the data returned when a hand is laid on a projected capacitive touchscreen (same technology as cellphones).

This is an example output of my Matlab function to convert any Z-map into a STL file.
The generated solid has a specified size(max) and thickness (min/max).
It's also possible to choose the degree of interpolation to smooth the output result. Are included 3 levels of interpolation. The explanation & script are available here: http://wp.me/p3gI7M-1S

comments.text: The Microchip sensor is also using mutual-capacitance (capacity measure between 2 electrodes). The Difference is in the number and shape of the electrodes. To detect the gestures at a few cm from the surface they are using 1 driver and 5 big receivers (see p11 http://ww1.microchip.com/downloads/en/DeviceDoc/41667A.pdf)http://ww1.microchip.com/downl.... This is great to "sense" gestures like shown in the video using only 5 measures. In the case of capacitive touch screens, the number of electrodes is vastly larger (the 15inches in this "thing" has 40*70~2800 intersections). So you get a very good resolution and you are able to detect multi-touch gestures.

title: Prusa i3 rework Y-endstop height extension

description.text:
The name pretty much says it all. When I built my Prusa i3, the Y endstop was not quite the right height to engage the build platform. So I designed a small add on to raise it about 10mm.  
This is my first experience with designing in OpenSCAD so I am sure it is pretty inelegant. It works though.
Should be printable as is. No support structures required.

author: Spiggles

description.text: Well, to be more technical, the flanged sliding bearing and the plastic spacer from the kit. I noticed a couple of parts in my MakerBot kit that looked like obvious printables, so in the time while I'm waiting for my remaining parts, I bodged up STL files for 'em. I'm not sure if it even ends up being economical to print these rather than buy them in the truckloads the MakerBot team will be getting them, but for the sake of quickly obtaining spares and for the general RepRap-ability of the system, it seemed worth the five minutes of modeling time. Plus, how can having an infinite supply of arbitrary-thickness board spacers be a bad thing?

This is a Thai inspired ornament which I have created as a finishing piece in a Thai booth which is placed on top of a pole and is painted gold. This is a big part which measures close to 30cm tall and the widest area is about 20cm in diameter.   
I have a single piece file and also in 3 separate parts. You can download as a single piece but will likely need to include supports in your print out due to the angles of some area. You will also need to shrink it smaller in order for it to fit properly in your print area.   
If you like to print it as the actual size, then you will need to print in the separate parts. Note that the base component is cut into half. You will need to print 2 pieces of that. Once all the parts are print, Just need to glue them together and you are done.

title: Zelda Hyrule Crest - Standing w/ leg bits - Print flat

description.text:
A remix of flameblade's Crest of Hyrule.  
I wanted a standing version of this print, but didn't want to print it standing up. The details of this lovely design come out much better if you print it on it's backside so I opted to make the supports separate bits.  
I didn't think it was much of a change compared to this overall awesome design, BUT flameblade still noticed :). & I'm not stingy, so rather than have him attempt to redo the work, I'm posting the edit up for all.  
It will stand up without the bits, but tips quite easily. If your display surface is unstable or not level you can print these small leg bits to keep it firmly planted!  
.. of course.. there's always double-sided tape ;)

Print the Crest.
Print the Bits.
Combine the parts.

This is an improved version of timschmidt's parametric shaft collar at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2454. In my original version, a tolerance parameter was added that can be used to improve the final size of the holes for the shaft, the clamping screw, and the trapped nut. The amount of material to be placed in front of the trapped nut was a new parameter. Finally, a parameter is provided for specifying the number of facets to be used. Rev A is mostly a refinement in how openSCAD is used, although improvements in the shaft collar result include chamfering of the shaft bore hole and shaping of the bottom of the nut slot to match a hexagon nut. The polyhole function from the MCAD library is now used for improved sizing of round holes. Instead of a single tolerance factor being applied to all dimensions, each parameter can now be individually adjusted. A table of standard dimensions for typical screw and nut hardware has been added as comments in the openSCAD file. Both the original and Rev A STL files are set up for an 8mm or 5/16 diameter shaft and an M3 clamping screw and standard M3 nut.

Open the SCAD file in openSCAD, edit the parameters at the top of the file for your application, render and export a new STL version. 
For the clamp to be somewhat flexible, keep the number of solid top and bottom layers to two, and slice with no more than 20% or 25% infill.  The overhanging arc over the notch for the screw head may lead to some drooping during printing.  Add some support in slicing to prevent it if desired.

I use my Note 2 to listen to music while I drive, but I wanted to use it as a dash cam as well. It sounded like another perfect opportunity to make a custom mount. Wanting to avoid suction cups that could fall off and to keep it away from the sun, I chose to hang it from the sun visor. Unless you drive a Ford Mondeo and have a Note 2 with this particular cover, you won't be able to just print it and use it as is. Just the same, here it is.  
In one of the pics, you will see a clip holding the Hanging Hook and the Shade Bracket. That is just to stop it from spinning when braking or turning hard. That's because the vertical spin axis is off center. I had to do that to place it as far away from my field of vision, but still be able to hang it from the visor. Without the clip, it won't fall, but will spin with most any turn, acceleration or deceleration.  
By the way, the dash cam app that I use is called AutoGuard.
Printed with about 40% infill, with no supports.

title: Kossel Mini 2020 Extrusion Adjustable Hexagonal Heated bed and Glass Clamp

description.text:
I got an idea for a Kossel Mini Bedclamp from this item:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:569373 But since my Kossel Mini is made from 2020 Extrusion it didn't fit. It seemed as easy enough for me to try to replicate in 123D so I did it :) A bit of tweaking and for me it works perfectly! As said it is for Kossel Mini with 2020 extrusion, Hexagonal Heatbed (AliExpres...) and 170mm/3mm Glass plate. Holes are for M5 screws. Enjoy!

What you need is 3x the parts. Attach the lower part to the extrusion, place heated bed and glass and align everything and screw down loose. Then one by one unscrew screws and place the glass holder on top and screw down again. Then one by one press the glass down firmly and the upper part agains the glass and screw down tight. It should hold everything just nice!

description.text: Star gears made in Morphi www.morphiapp.com In Morphi, users of all skill levels can make 3D printable objects on the go using touch, without wifi or a mouse. www.morphiapp.com Download the app for free for iPad and IPad mini on the App Store. https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/morphi/id833530351?mt=8 Coming soon for Android! Copyright 2014-2015, The Inventery, Inc.

This model was made in Morphi app using the free cylinders and the star from the paid shapes pack. www.morphiapp.com. We have included one .STL file with the base and the gears. No support is needed. We printed the base first. Then we switched out the color in our printer and printed the gears in a different color. Here is a video of the final print on our YouTube channel. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ysndNsVFolI Print our model or design your own in the app. Download Morphi for free on the App store. https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/morphi/id833530351?mt=8 Coming soon for Android.

author: kettlechris

description.text: Designed to use the hot shoe mount to hold your GoPro.  Great for getting extra footage on shoots or recording low res video for previewing shots. This design uses friction to keep your GoPro firmly attached to your camera, allowing you to move your camera quickly with out worrying about it slipping out.

This is a quick-and-dirty replacement for a missing hammer on an upright piano. Video at http://www.flickr.com/photos/ranjit/5430307892/ The pictured hammers were lasercut from 1/4" poplar, glued together in pairs to be 1/2" thick and then sanded down to 0.4" to match the original hammers. The extended slot in the bottom allows you to glue the hammer onto the old broken shafts instead of replacing them, and to tilt them to the right to hit the strings at the right angle. The felt is some wool stuff from a craft drawer. Real hammer heads are mostly felt, but I made these ones mostly wood because it was easier.

This design is intended to replace a lost hammer that was broken off very close to the top of the shaft.  If the stump of the broken shaft is too short, you'll have to replace or splint the shaft.
Choose your wood stock so that you can approximately match the thickness of the hammers in your piano.  It would probably be easier and work as well to use three layers of 1/8" wood rather than two layers of 1/4" followed by several minutes at the disc sander.  
After cutting, glue the layers together and sand down if necessary.  
Cut strips of felt and glue them to the rounded surface of the hammer.  I used wood glue here, and two layers of ordinary craft felt.  Although only the very front of the felt actually hits the strings, wrapping the felt around to the back of the hammer head gives it much more surface area to glue, making it less likely to fall off in use.
Dab a fair amount of glue into the slot, let the glue thicken for a minute or so, and fit it onto the broken shaft.  (Be careful to wipe up any drips so you don't glue your piano together!  I also placed scraps of paper to help keep things from sticking together.)  As the glue hardens, you can adjust the tilt and rotation of the hammer so that it hits the strings at the right angle.
I don't know how long these hammers will last before they fall apart or fall off the shafts, but it's better than having a big gap in the middle of the piano!

Thanks for the Marble Machine files.  Here is my version.  I modified the base by adding some holes.  Two of the holes are under the motor mount so you are able to screw on the mount after the parts are assembled.  One hole is near the motor mount to put wires through to the Battery Base.  4 large holes around the perimeter allow you to snap on the Battery Base I designed.  The Battery Base holds a place for a battery holder that takes 4 AA batteries.  It also houses a slot for an on/off switch.  I have included both the stl files as well as the Sketchup files in case you want to modify anything.

On my first attempt, I found that the diameter of the  holes was too small to accommodate 1/4-inch hex bits.

title: Makita Compact Cordless Drill Bit Holder

description.text: If you have a Makita compact cordless drill (1/2", though it probably works on the 3/8" and 1/4"versions too), you know it will come with a small flat/phillips head bit that is just loose in the box. I like to keep that attached to the drill when not in use, else it be lost, so I created this little attachment that sits on top and holds the bit in place (tension).

Just go ahead and print it. I've included the original STL file as well as a 200 micron layer (0.2mm) gcode file for the Printrbot Simple Metal (10 minutes to print). I also included the original SketchUp 2015 file for those who want to mess with it.

title: Velleman Vertex K8400 Front hatch kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted a transparent door for my Velleman Vertex K8400 printer.
This kit contains hinges, a no contact magnet lock, some assembly time mounting clips, and instructions for making the acrylic glass door itself. http://youtu.be/BnveS9R1kpo Please scale prints to 1/10, as this is a Sketchup design.
All parts are in millimeters. For you with access to a suitable CNC of any sort, a drawing of the door itself is kindly posted by wreutz:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2317942

For further instructions please see:
http://youtu.be/BnveS9R1kpo Please scale prints to 1/10, as this is a Sketchup design. Cut the door out from 4 mm acrylic glass or similar.
Use the front panel as a template.
Cut the door at least 1.5 mm smaller than the opening in every direction, as it is mounted in flush with the front panel.
Use a file to smoothen the edges.
Polish to make them shine. The hinges are fastened to the front panel with two hexagon socket M5 x 16 mm screws, two M5 washers, and two M5 locking nuts. The hinges are fastened to the hatch with four hexagon socket M5 x 12 mm screws, and two M5 locking nuts. The lock requires two ø10 x 2.5 [mm], (coin shaped), neodymium magnets, two M3 x 10 mm flat head screws, and two M3 locking nuts.
And for a click free operation, some PVA-glue in the magnet compartments. (For those of you who have a Clas Ohlson shop near by, their art nr 31-1467 are the magnets that i bought.)

The Thing-O-Matic gets kind of hard to light externally, since one side is completely closed off. I remembered this little ring of LEDs I'd purchased a long time ago for another project, and as luck would have it, it exactly fits the wooden extruder opening on the ToM. Here's a link to the exact light I am using:
http://www.dealextreme.com/p/t10-24-led-white-light-car-angel-eye-80mm-diameter-26001 This light is SO BRIGHT it lights the entire chamber, but the EXTREME INTENSENESS of it just made my camera take horrible photos of the lights themselves when on. So I took some off, too. You can see my power switch is just taped to the corner of my 'bot; if I were more clever with design I'd make a little housing for it. Maybe someone wants to offer some aid.

Print 2-4 of the Lightmount.stl. Multiply works wonders here. While you're waiting for those to print (doesn't take long!) find a spare switch, and wire some long leads onto the light ring, attaching one of the leads to the power switch in the usual fashion. This isn't rocket surgery. The switch is, of course, optional. Make sure you keep track of which lead is + and which is -; they're clearly labeled on the ring. As you can see, I used the same colored wires, then I twisted them, making it impossible to know which I'd attached to + and -. I figured it out by laying the leads against a 9v battery, which shouldn't be enough to blow things up the wrong way around. When it lit up, I put a green tag on the - end. :) This takes 12v, so I wired mine directly into the spare 4-wire connector on the ATX power supply... the one that provides 2 12v+ (+ from the ring goes here) and 2 GND (- goes here) connections (see here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ATX_PS_signals.jpg and pictures for reference). You could also just put it in the FAN port on your extruder controller, if you never hooked up the fan there (and aren't using it for the ABP motor). LET EVERYTHING COOL DOWN after you print and before you try to hook this up! I know that sounds dumb, but in my impatience I nearly burned my hand on the hot end. You will see the ring fits neatly into the small slot (the mounts should fit between the LEDs), and the big slot should slip neatly over the wood of the Z axis. You can get by just fine on 1, 2 is plenty. I only put another 2 on the front of mine so they'd be easier to see in the photos.

comments.text: I'm curious about something...does the heat from the hot ends cause any problems?  Seeing this idea prompted me to cannibalize the ring light from my Canon unit.  I have a duel extruder with barely 3/4" from the hot ends to the edge of the light ring...is it going to fry it?

comments.text: What's sad, is everything that guy sells in his shop, is from something that someone made here...not one damn thing is his design.  I'm all for taking bits and pieces and making it your own, but he copied my hole pattern, and refuses to take it down...without getting all legal about it.
comments.author: LucidPsykosis

comments.text: Yeah, he and I have had that conversation.  He stated that, "I have used your stock image and if you wish I will take it down. The model however,  although inspired by your design was custom made by me. I measured your design with vernier calipers once printed and built this model from scratch.  Copyright law states one cannot copyright simple geometric figures which this is. Also since my design was created by me and used your design as inspiration it is also not copyright infringement even if you could copyright simple geometric figures.
comments.author: LucidPsykosis

comments.text: Unfortunately that is fairly accurate. There are limitations on what can be patented and simple geometric design is indeed one of those things. Similarly there are laws to protect infringement on product being sold in the market currently. So basically you would have a case if you could prove a steady sales-stream existed before this guy started profiting off your work. Likewise, if you had branded the product and introduced it to the retail market via wholesale or distributing partners, you may be able to fight this. Outside of that however, he is well within his rights to modify and resell, no matter how slight the variation is.
comments.author: LucidPsykosis

comments.text: Since this was two years ago, I've changed my outlook on 3D printing and its pitfalls.  I think it's funny you decided to offer your take on it after this long, but whatever.  Your comment on someone's intentions for buying a printer are misguided.  I know MANY people who's original intentions were far from wanting to make stuff for sale.  My first printer was a FlashForge Dreamer, and I paid $1100 for it.  My intentions were to make props and such, as I'm not good at it otherwise.  It was only after people wanting to buy these props, did I think about selling.  As far as other people, whether they had no knowledge of how to build one or just wanted a quality printer, is their prerogative.  This is a HOBBY, thus it can be for fun or otherwise.  The sad thing is, I've noticed a level of elitism with some people who are skilled at building printers and knowing how to make a great print.  For example, I can tear apart/ reassemble an AH-64 Longbow Apache attack helicopter with my eyes shut. Do I tell a someone interested in it, 'unless you're mechanically inclined, this isn't for you'? No...because it's not my place to dictate how they spent their time and money.  Wow this went on and on...but you get my point.  Try not to offended by my rantings.  I'm out of coffee so you caught me on a bad day.
comments.author: Malooga

comments.text: My comments are proof of my opinion, and therefore not misguided in the least. I bought an $800 printer, made a few small items to pitch to local head shops and earned that $800 back in just short of 4 months. It's amazing what you can do with a little elbow grease, and it has nothing to do with an "elitist" attitude. I also got a chuckle at the "don't take offense" part even though you clearly felt some sort of way about my reply. I don't really care if it was posted 10 years ago, I saw it today and replied, so there's that mystery solved. I don't really take any point at all, other than you wanted me to know you can assemble a helicopter? Gratz on that. You seemed confused about the legality of what was happening, so I attempted to clear things up. I don't really monitor my "phrasing" on the internet, because I could give a shit what people think of me, but just to clear it up for you-it was meant to be a helpful response. That of course, was not how it came across as is obvious by your essay on willpower, so I decided to respond in kind. I don't know much about helicopters, but I know how to turn a profit. That's what I did with my printer, and I think its foolish for people not to...but again, my opinion. Try not to let it ruin your day, its just not that important. :)
comments.author: LucidPsykosis

author: gooses

title: If-Off-Stay-Off Box, power loss safety device

description.text:
The if-off-stay-off box is a cheap tool for protecting electro-mechanical devices from damaging themselves following a power outage by preventing them from turning back on when the power returns.   
If the if-off-stay-off is unplugged and re-plugged in then it will remain OFF until the button is pressed (then it will remain ON until unplugged again).  
I designed this for a friend who was worried about his fish tank filter pump, which needed manual priming to operate properly and would be damaged if allowed to run dry (which would happen following a power outage).   
Of course an uninterruptible power supply (UPS) is the preferred option for protecting  devices during a power outage, but they also cost about $60. Perhaps you can think of alternatives uses for this device anyway; Practical jokes maybe?

Make sure to use correctly sized wire and relay for your specific power requirements. You can find a free wire sizing calculator here: http://engineerdog.com/2015/01/05/free-electrical-wire-gauge-sizing-calculator/ In my experience project boxes are best printed solid or else the outer layer doesn’t bind well to the inside and you end up with a weak box. Version 1 uses a single pole single throw (or double throw) relay.
Version 2 uses a double pole single throw (or double throw) relay and is recommended.
Both versions use the same case. Shopping List:
(1) 120VAC Socket Plug: http://amzn.to/1dYl2dr (1) Relay: http://amzn.to/1Jd1wra (1) Momentary Switch: http://amzn.to/1SBsQAZ (1) Three Wire Power Cord: http://amzn.to/1HszYrG

comments.text: Add a NC momentary switch in series with the existing switch and then you have an emergency (or general purpose) stop switch

title: Pentax K-mount SLR to 1.25" telescope eyepiece adapter

description.text: This is something I whipped up to go stargazing with a friend. It allows you to take pictures through the telescope with pretty much any Pentax camera that uses a K mount.

I printed mine with black PLA, two walls, 20% infill and with a part fan it printed without the need for any supports. Tested with my Pentax K-x.   
NOTE: The mount is supposed to be a snug fit to prevent light from leaking in. If your printer is not well calibrated or your slicer doesn't handle small details well, you may have to do some filing. Also, for the sake of your camera please ensure it is locking properly before using it!

author: xzivr

title: Prince Wednesday's Castle Playset
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My daughter is obsessed with Daniel Tiger, the PBS show, and one of her favorite characters is Prince Wednesday. There is no playset you can purchase of his castle, so I created a castle playset that is inspired by the facade on the show. It is hardly a replica, but it'll tide her over until they make one I can buy! I have an old Printrbot JR so I needed it to be able to fit on a 150x150 print bed... so, some assembly required to fit the pieces together!!! Update 1/8: I added two covers for the bottom towers so if you are printing the roofs in different colors than the walls, you can have a bit o' visual uniformity. I also updated the spacerconnector file to fit better. Update 1/11: I've added a 2nd version of the top left tower and some "little clippy things" if you want to clip it to the back of the roof... if you don't want your tower permanently glued or just sitting on the top, here's a solution! Top right tower to come later this week. I've got my roofs printed, and I'm waiting for blue filament (it'll be way too blue, but it'll have to work) in the mail to do the full assembly. If you want a big neighborhood trolley, go here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:630018

The "assembled" file is just so you can see how it all fits together...  don't try to print it (or do and let me know if it is a disaster?!?!)  
The sections each have little slots built in, and you can print a bunch of the "Spacers" and use them to glue the sections together, if you don't want to come apart... or just shove them in there and (if your printer as sloppy like mine) they'll probably stay together out of friction!

title: TomTom XL Cradle for Toyota Hilux Cup Holder

description.text:
After fixing a TomTom XL which had it's USB SMD socket ripped off, I needed a simple attachment device for my Toyota Hilux,   
Using a three (3) piece design, a ball/socket mechanism allows rotation of Tomtom and the cupholder clip allows cradle to slide along edge of cup holder.  The Tomtom holding frame pins the GPS in eight (8) points, making it very secure...  
A jubilee (pipe clamp) has been added to add the required tightness to the  ball/socket mechanism.  This reduces stress forces on plastic and should stop the 3D plastic from failing prematurely.. Shall let you know how many km the  cradle lasts for.

description.text: Constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 1.9 million polygons). It was made using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

Have yet to print the model. I took it directly from the game files, ran it through Netfabb and saved as an STL in Meshmixer.  
Update. I did a test print on my up mini but had to scale it down a lot to fit in the build space. Because of this, i cut the model into reasonable size chunks. Scaled down to 25% and built on fine print quality with big honeycomb. Estimated print time of around 40 hours. I have finished the head and will slow print each part. I uploaded the cut files which i may need to split and reload again due to print size.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fUdg0xy7x4F I made this to hookup to motherboards so I could simulate end stops and thermistors. LED s thru series resisters (470 ohms) are hooked to bed and extruder heaters outputs and 3rd for fan or lights . Variable resisters simulate thermistors.
Printed @ 3mm 40% infill. Instructions in description

Printer Wobbling? Didn't spend two days making sure every single angle was perfect on your brand new printrbot? (didn't shell out for a metal one?) Look no further!  
This was printed in ninja-flex to absorb vibration and increase the friction between the table and the printer (to stop it sliding).  It worked Marvelously.  Any flexible filament should have a similar effect.  No idea how well this would work if it were printed in rigid filament, probably not great.  
The mrk2 will be bigger, have a wider bottom surface area and slot over top of the screw heads so that, in case you shake your printer really hard while you're carrying it, the feet wont fall off! As is, they stay on pretty well even while in transit.

title: Bracket to Re-purpose Shoe Rack to Plant Trellis

description.text:
I had one of those simple wooden shoe racks hanging around, like in the 3rd picture, and decided to convert it to a wall mounted trellis for my climbing plant.  
The actual 3D printed part is a simple custom bracket to hold the shoe rack close to the wall.  The part of the bracket where the wooden rack sits is 19mm wide.  I've included the SketchUp file (.skp) if you wish to modify it.

Nothing special, just print 2 brackets per shoe rack and screw into the wall. My gcode Settings

UPDATE
Durwin Pye has sorted out the Scad file so it is now brilliant, Thanks,
I have added it to the list of files -not for the faint of heart- After printing some other designs and finding they did not work for me, I decided to have a go myself, So here it is, Please beware, I have made allowances for my own printer so I take no resonsibility if it doesnt work for you.
Also, to state the obvious, this is a plastic chuck, it has its limits!.
101mm diameter, 59mm thick plus 25mm jaw height.
With thanks to;
-Parametric Involute Bevel and Spur Gears by GregFrost
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575
-Customizable Spiral Generator by walter
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58406
for the hard work
UPDATE
I have printed and tested (sort of) different jaw materials And added photos
ABS,......................Best grip
Flexi at 85% infill ..2nd -being flexible they grab well
PLA ......................3rd, ok but tend to over tighten, which could break the scroll
NYLON..................3rd equal Thanks to MrArrow1961 for the reverse jaws thingiverse.com/thing:624814 Check out this awesome assembly video https://vimeo.com/137431844
by yuri9999! http://www.thingiverse.com/make:155862 I have not included the Scad file at the moment, as it is a real mess,
if I can tidy it up I will post at a latter date-DONE
Thanks to Durwin Pye for cleaning the scad.

I have added photos for reference,
Print,
1 face housing
1 rear housing, either bolt hole which is more stable, or 10mm hex
1 scroll
1 gear ring
3 drive gear
1 of each jaw 1, 2 and3
the jaws are numbered as they have to be inserted in the correct order to get them to align.
You will need 1 M8 hex key for the drive gears, mine is a very snug fit. I printed at 0.25mm layer height, 35% honeycomb infill
and sliced with slic3r 1.1.7, using a 0.4mm nozzle.
Please check the resulting code for possible problems before you print, especially perimeters around holes 7x M3 by 8mm long screws, (I cut down longer ones)
they are to attach the scroll to the gear ring, do not over tighten, or you will strip out the plastic
3x M4 by about 40mm long screws, these hold the drive gears in place, I had to file the head down on my ones so they would fit.
6x M4 by about 20/30mm screws to hold the back plate on
1x M10 bolt and nut for the drive shaft You will also need small files and sandpaper to touch up any lumps and bumps from printing, also maybe to smooth the gear ring inner and outer surface etc.
Please be aware, I found the print supports for the face housing tricky to remove, be patient and use a file to clean up if needed to get the jaws in
Also drill bits to clear the holes
** Test fit the jaws in the face housing before inserting anything else as these will most likely need a little filing, they should fit in and slide freely but not sloppy.
Once everything is cleaned up and fits freely, screw the scroll and gear ring together not tight, and drop in to the housing, fit the 3 drive gears and screw in the M4 locking screws
take your M8 hex key and make sure the gears turn easy then advance the scroll until you see the start of the thread, back it up a bit and insert Jaw1, advance the scroll it should start pulling the jaw in then insert jaw 2, then 3, screw on the back plate and your good to go.
Good luck.

comments.text:
I just printed the chuck. Excellent design.
Here are my few observations:
1/ I could not make my slicer to slice the built in supports on face housing. So I went to included scad file and rendered my own stl without supports. I used Simplify for slicing and adding necessary supports. Printed just fine in about 8 hours on Prusa i3 MK2. What was my surprise when I saw reinforced part of inner bore on new face housing. Then I found new piece of code in scad file marked "////DP: New feature". That means I cannot use the original scroll part as its centre hole is small now. So I had to tweak the code for scroll a bit.
2/ I decided to tweak the drive gear part after I snapped the outer pin on one of them. I wanted to make a 3mm hole in the pin axis and glue piece of 3mm diameter filament in the hole to reinforce the pin. something like this, but using the filament instead of screw: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:674853
However, now after exporting new drive gear, there is deeper and bigger grove around the gear (the one where the locking screw goes. I cannot make it more shallow. When I tweak the variable "pin_radius=(3+clearance);" to something like pin_radius=(2+clearance); the teeth simply disappear. I cannot find why.

I have found that PLA is best as it is strong and rigid, no flex
ABS has flex .

comments.text: Dear Bob, I have question to rear housing element (cap) - why it has so high  vertical walls if scroll & gear ring abut to the drive gears? In my version I am going to cut those walls because they are creating additional friction force when I want to open or close chuck's jaws. I will leave only 2,5mm height.
comments.author: MrArrow1961

comments.text:
MrArrow1961, The high walls act as a bearing surface against the back of the scroll gear, that is why the gear ring is a smaller diameter than the scroll gear
if you cut the wall off and tighten the chuck, the drive gears will take all load, this could lead to the ends breaking off the drive gears, Your remix using a 3mm screw as a pin may stop this , however the load will still be against the gears
There shouldn't be too much friction, I would suggest removing only a small amount say 0.25mm so that it wont bind, also check that the gear ring outer diameter is less than the inner diameter of the rear housing walls so it can turn freely.
Bob.
comments.author: MrArrow1961

comments.text:
Ok print times etc, using Slic3r 1.1.7- 0.4mm nozzle, home made hotend, home made Mendel90 with extruder mounted on X carriage and 3mm filament, (Lots of things here that limit print speed before even looking at slice settings).
3 top and bottom layers, 3 perimeters, 35% honeycomb fill, 50mm/sec perimeter, with exterior perimeter at 80% of that, 60mm/s infill, 50mm/s top solid infill 180mm/s non print moves, results in;
-Face Housing 8hours 48 min using 16.5m filament
-Gear ring 2 hours 11min using 3.854m filament
-3 Drive Gears 2 hours 20min using 4.258m filament
If I was to slice with Cura with above settings (except honeycomb infil) my print times would be faster still as it seems to slice differently .
I could speed that up even on my printer , however I would end up with less quality and a print result where parts may not fit together as well as they should, or as previously mentioned weaker parts.
Now I could print these parts out on my other printer which uses 1.75mm filament and has better bearings, much faster but my old trusty printer prints fine and Im not really in any huge hurry.
I would be interested in your printer and slicing settings and a photo of your prints to compare?
Bob.

comments.text:
Dear Bob, what polymer did you used for drive gears? PLA more hard but brittle, the ABS more elastic not so hard like PLA and not too much brittle.
Moreover, since drive gear printed in vertical position the polymer fiber structure lies in the horizontal direction and in the same direction it is under load and break the seam. If we will turn drive gear to 90 degrees to print then the force of the pressure will fall against the polymer fiber axis and can not break it.But at this case, we are forced to use the support structure that will decline the quality of printed gear teeth .This is not desirable. Therefore, I recommend using a metal screw in body of axis and print object vertically.
(Sorry for my poor English, hope I had explained all correct.)
comments.author: bobwomble

comments.text: Also was an tapping of the holes needed?
comments.author: Bri113

comments.text:
Don't tap the holes, run an appropriate drill through to clean the hole,(2.5mm drill for a 3mm bolt) then slowly screw the bolt into the hole which will cut the thread for you, if you wind the screw in to fast it heats up and melts the plastic, effectively striping the hole out. I have found with PLA that if you tap the holes, the tap seems to make the hole to big and you end up with a sloppy fit.
Bob.
comments.author: Bri113

comments.text: If u Form the thread with a threadformer(Not a threadcutter) or with a screw, you have to make the hole bigger then the regular hole for a M3 thread. 2,7mm will work better.

I only have experience with my home built mendel90, I don't see any reason why you would have any problems, but I would stick to settings that you have had success with in the past.
I have never used a raft, and the only support you need is built in to the design (on the face housing it is little hollow cubes at the bottom, should be pretty obvious)
The parts were designed for 0.25mm layer height as that is what I mostly use, different layer heights shouldn't cause too much of a problem, although It will slightly change the location of some parts in the z direction, nothing a file or sand paper wont fix. The problems you are having sound more like mechanical or slicer type settings to me.
Do you check your G code before you print? (I am guessing you can do that on you Makerbot s/w)

I struggled with printing out the other bottom I found on here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:469267/#comments that used retention clips, and found that the retention clips didn't really hold the bottom securely. I build this new bottom out from scratch. This uses the standard m3 screws that printrbot uses. Just drop in the nuts, drill 4 small holes that line up with the screw holes, and mount in place. This should be plenty secure. Note that I have a fair amount of ventilation here but my printrbot has a fan so if you don't have a fan mounted on the front you may want to consider doing so when adding this bottom since you will be reducing airflow. The fan mount I used can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:376515

On my FlashForge (Replicator Dual clone) the spool holders are great for the fatter spools, but I have gotten a few that are skinny, and the spool drifts back & forth along the post.  That leads to the filament getting tangled and other nasty stuff.  
Support Me Please

If you like my stuff please check out my Lego R2-D2's blog at http://L3-G0.com or L3-G0's Youtube, and please tweet or Facebook a link to his page. He's cool and every visitor helps support my maker habit, thanks!

I've put my filament guide tube down over the spool so it can't "fall out" of the spool, keeping the filament on the spool.  (When the tube was higher, sometimes it would pull the filament off the edge of the spool and wrap it around the post).  Unfortunately the skinny spools walk along the post, and out from under the guide tube.  Using the spacers before the nut allows the spool to stay where it's supposed to.  
Instructions

Print both spacers.  Then when you have a "narrow" spool, use one or both spacers to fill most of the gap.  I seem OK with 1-2CM of a gap, but more than that caused trouble.  The spacers are different widths because so are the various spools I've bought.  
Support Me Please

If you like my stuff please check out my Lego R2-D2's blog at http://L3-G0.com or L3-G0's Youtube, and please tweet or Facebook a link to his page. He's cool and every visitor helps support my maker habit, thanks!

This soap dish is inspired by modern bathtub designs I have seen.  There is a slight slope to the insert where the soap sits such that it is supposed to drain into the base though the hole in the middle but the slope turns out as a terraced effect when printed that I wasn't expecting but that looks kind of cool at the same time.

Made in Blender.  Printed on a RigidBot using PLA at 0.2mm layer height, 0.8mm shell, 10% fill, 195C print head temp, 55C bed temp, no supports. I printed using Cura as the slicer, and it took around 3.5 hours at the default scale.  
I've only tried to print this on one type of PLA extrusion printer so your experience may vary.  I've included the Blender file in case anyone would like to make changes/improvements/derivatives, etc.  Have fun.  
Depending on your soap size, you may need to scale this up.  This was designed to be a snug fit for Dove soap as that is what I use most, but it should scale well.

A 3D printable virtual reality headset that uses your smartphone. inspired by the popular Google cardboard VR headset. this version was designed after my cardboard started falling apart (RIP). It uses two 25mm diameter 40mm focal length bi-convex lenses (sold on Amazon) to focus on SBS (side by side) 3D video and apps from your smart phone. Features:
Rubber band hooks to attach your smartphone.
Finger access ports to tap your screen when wearing the device.
Snap fit lens covers
Two head mounting options (see instructions).

You will need:
-Two 25mm diameter 40mm focal length bi-convex lenses (same used with Google cardboard).
-Two rubber bands. Optional:
-A GroPro head strap with mounting screw
-Or elastic material to make a head strap. Assembly:
  • Print either the GoPro head strap version (PrintVR_GoPro_Strap.stl) or the generic head strap version (PrintVR_HeadStrap.stl). Remove built in support material around lens holders and mouse ears around the base perimeter.
  • Print one of the lens covers
  • Check the fit of the lens cover with the head unit. the lens cover should press into the head unit eye socket with slight resistance and require a small amount of force to disassemble. If the lens cover fits loosely try scaling the stl file up by a very small amount and re-print. if it does not fit then try scaling the stl file down a small amount and re-print.
  • Once the fit dialed in, print another lens cover, place the 25mm diameter lenses into the head unit and install the lens covers to trap them.
  • Attach your smart phone using rubber bands and enjoy!

title: Spring loaded extruder for Leapfrog Creatr

description.text:
The Creatr from Leapfrog (www.lpfrg.com) has a fixed idler ball bearing. I wanted to replace this by a spring loaded type to allow better control over the filament feed and allow for an easier filament change.
After a few different ideas, the Mk7 minimalistic replacement extruder seemed a nice design to start with and here is the result.
Now changing colors is actually a fun thing to do ;)
Update: I found that the pressure on the filament was not always enough so I moved the spring and compressed it a bit more resulting in more pressure on the spring. I've tested this for > 100 hours with ABS, Taulman Nylon and PLA and had no problems at all.
Also added a longer filament guide towards the hobbed wheel, making a filament change a bit easier.
note: photos with the light green parts are v2, red parts are v1
You could consider building http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:321258 instead, this adds the possibility to print flexible filaments like Arnitel and Ninjaflex

Print and follow the instructions in the PDF document. The PDF document contains detailed instructions on how to remove the old extruder parts and install the new one.
N.b: the instructions are still for v1 but v2 is almost the same (except for the washers when mounting the stepper motor).
You do not need to remove any wiring or cut or change original parts. Everything can be restored to its original state if needed.
Besides the printed parts (and some tools) you will also need:
  • about 12 3mm washers
  • 2x 3mm nylon washers (I prefer those for lower friction)
  • 2x M3x25 screws
  • 1x M4x15 screw
  • 1x M4 nut
  • 1x spring (25mm x OD 10mm)
    I used a spring from reprapworld.com (http://reprapworld.com/?products_details&products_id=228&cPath=16160), the same type is available from different shops.

I had problem extruding with my leapfrog creatr, so i try your solution.
It is better but i still have some problem: sometimes (often) the filament stops extruding during an instant which mean at the end i had gap in my piece. Te motor is running but the wheel stops and so i had no filament coming out.
Do you have an idea? Im using a diferent spring than yours, do you think it can be because of that?
SIncerely
comments.author: bibilabibi

comments.text:
Hm... motor is running but the wheel stops ?
If this is true, you should see the axle of the motor rotating while the wheel is not. In that case the wheel slips on the axle and you have to re-tighten the little allen screw (imbus) of the wheel. If I remember well this is a 1.5mm allen screw
comments.author: bibilabibi

comments.text: Sorry i did not want to said that. I was talking about the ball bearing which is not rotating whereas the wheel of the motor is rotating.
comments.author: Rob65

comments.text:
If the wheel at the motor is rotating and the ball bearing not, then the transportation of the filament stopped.
This is most likely due to not enough pressure from the spring. I had a few problems with this myself - try another spring or increase the pressure from the washed by placing a large washer or a thin piece of steel under the spring so it becomes stronger.
comments.author: bibilabibi

comments.text:
Hi again,
I replace your spring by a stronger one, it works really well now.
Thanks for sharing that Rob !

comments.text: I'm having trouble getting mine to feed correctly.  Is the spring you used really stiff? I found a pretty stiff one at Lowes (Bi Folding Door Replacement Hardware) that I cut to size.  The spring is strong enough that it is difficult to assemble.  Without filament, the drive roll spins the idler bearing, but with filament the bearing does not turn.  It may be that I need to clean my hot zone, as it is fairly difficult to manually push the filament in.
comments.author: chickan

comments.text:
just measured my spring. Uncompressed it is 25mm long and 10mm wide. When I compress the spring to about 16mm (that;s approximately how long the spring is when compressed in the extruder) it develops about 1.5 kg force.
I just measured this by placing the spring on my kitchen scales and then pushing it until it is about 16mm long. The scale now shows 1500 grams.
And that actually is a bit on the low side. I currently have the spring compressed a bit more to develop about 2 kg force.
comments.author: chickan

comments.text: I think the issue was with my hotzone requiring too much force.  I switched to the other extruder and only one moderate spring was sufficient.  Printing great now!  I'll have to clean the one hot zone thouroughly and see if it is easier to push filament through.  I print exclusively in PLA these days, directly on the heated glass with a bit of hair spray.
comments.author: Rob65

comments.text: Nice to read it works. I am still working on a design with a longer lever and an adjustment for the spring force but I am not yet convinced about my new design.

Robot grip with Tower Pro SG90 micro servo.
Video of first test: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oDkd662i65g

This is another part of my ongoing process of designing a drybox that will hang on the side of my Airwolf HD2x printer.  This thing will be useful for other folks too.  I have a nearly completed set of drawings for a sealed Plexiglass box that will have a hinged door and a universal spool holder.  So here is what I have for the spool holder.  The idea is that it should be able to handle the 3 most common spool inner hole diameters: 0.78", 1.25", and 2.05".  These holders do not turn.  The smallest diameter will be able to hold the small spools with Nylon.  It is intended to be reinforced with a 4 3/4" x 1/4" bolt.  The other two spindles will slide over the top of the smaller one.   
I will post the drawings for the entire box when I am finished with it.  See the teaser picture of what I am shooting for.

author: jasonchiou

description.text:
Removed stencil background and made it 3mm thick.  
Removed charging hole on bottom of case and shortened the hole for the power button. This increases structural rigidity.  
Added two 3mm thick loops on each side of the case. I was not able to break these loops off with my hands.

Printed with ABS, 0.3mm layer height.
3mm brim, no raft.
I used pillar supports to print this. Most likely not needed, but it doesn't hurt. If you are printing this with ABS, I would advise you wipe down the case with acetone to increase the strength of the case. The acetone will dissolve the acetone and cause it to stick to the other layers very well.
I took a cutip and wiped down the corners really well so it doesn't snap there. Using a lanyiard, or a small rope you tie it around both of the loops. Then you put two loops in the rope: One that is far away(approximately two or three feet) and one that is close(3-6inches). Attach carabiner to the two loops and you are ready to go. The close carabiner should be attached when you are actually climbing, and the one farther away is for when you want to take a picture. This allows you to keep the phone connected to you at all times.

description.text: Gerald's medallion from The Witcher game series.

This is a scan from an official the Witcher medallion. 07/04/2013 : Model has been cleaned-up and scaled to full size. I printed it one time at half size to check it and it print well. I'm printing a full size one now. (beware that the nose need proper cooling to not mess it) 16/03/2013 : Beware this is still a work in progress and need some more cleaning to be really perfect.
The current model has some kind of artifact in the back but should be printable since it has been processed through 3ds max and Netfabb.
The model need to be resized in order to be representative (I will put the correct scaled model later on this page).
